characters: TAMMY WYNETTE'S "STAND BY YOUR MAN" OVER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A 7-year-old BOBBY sits in a chair, his feet dangling in absent-minded rhythm to a chamber piece played by his father, his two brothers and his sister.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON a metronome, marking a slow etude rhythm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The CAMERA MOVES from it to Bobby, on the piano bench beside his mother. As she patiently demonstrates the etude for him, he places a thumb in his mouth and leans against her arm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ON THE METRONOME at an andante rhythm. CARL and TITA, now in their teens, are seated side by side on the piano bench, playing four-hands with dazzling virtuosity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The CAMERA MOVES from them to a framed newspaper article on the music-room wall. Below a photograph of a 20-year-old young man are the words: "Herbert Kreutzer Dupea - Seattle's Youngest Guest Conductor."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bobby, at 10, wearing a dress suit. His mother combs his hair with maternal concentration.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE-UP of a program announcing a Dupea family recital. The CAMERA SCANS down the bill, over:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sonata in C Major for Two Violins - Bach - Played by Nicholas and Carl Dupea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like As a Lovelorn Turtle - Hendel - Sung by Isabelle Dupea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rondo Alla Turca - Mozart - Played by Elizabeth Dupea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Piano Sonata, Opus 110 - Beethoven - Played by Herbart Dupea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The CAMERA COMES to rest on:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Five Easy Pieces - Grebner - Played by Robert Dupea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Five Easy Pieces, played haltingly OVER the torsos of a line of people moving slowly down the chapel aisle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: shows a solemn procession of the above, filing by an open casket holding Isabelle Dupea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The CAMERA PANS from NICHOLAS, seated on the aisle, to the four adult children seated next to him and COMES TO REST on Bobby. His gaze is cast down to his lap, as he refuses to look at:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The pale profile of his mother's face resting within the satin folds of the casket lining, and...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... as the last of the "family friends" pay their respect: Nicholas steps out into the aisle and, followed by Tita, Carl and HERBERT, moves down toward the casket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bobby rises from his seat and makes his way toward the aisle, where he hesitates briefly, then turns and walks up the aisle and out the chapel doors.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The toothed bucket of a back hoe trenches into the earth, then lifts up into the air, revealing Bobby in hard-hat and heavy gloves, operating the levers. As the hoe swings off to the side and deposits a load of earth into the rear of a truck...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... a SERIES OF SHOTS begins, showing Bobby and a fellow hard-hat (ELTON) engaged in the dirty and dangerous task of working "crew" with a team of TOOL-PUSHERS on the derricks of Signal Hill. Functioning as servants of the well and its pumps, the PULL rods, MAKE and BREAK joints on the rig floor, WELD tubing, CARRY pipes, CLIMB the "tour," and PLAY THE DOZENS on beer wagon breaks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bobby, still in his hard hat, as he drives. Out through the window, the derricks of the Hill can be seen, their night-work lights on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FOLLOWING ON the car as it moves off the Hill into the seamy districts adjacent to it, passing by fast food joints, liquor stores, all-night porno parlors and neon-lighted bars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as he stares out through the windshield, his eyes distant, dwelling in an oblivion that blanks both the present and past.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The car pulls onto a low-rent residential street and comes to a stop in front of a small bungalow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bobby exits the car, moves up the walkway to the house and disappears inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bobby, seated on the couch, a can of beer in hand, staring morosely across the room, to:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: playing the song:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "And if you love him/Oh be proud of him/For after all, he's just a man..."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: in a waitress's uniform with a bowl of beer nuts. After placing them on the coffee table in front of him, she leans down and kisses him. Challenged by a less than reciprocal response, she kisses him more fervently. As she moves her lips from his ear to his neck, he lifts the can to his mouth and drinks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Stand by your man/And show the world you love him/Keep giving all the love you can/Stand by your man."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The song concludes, and setting aside her ardor for the moment:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Arky accent) I'm gonna play it again...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As she starts for the stereo, he takes hold of her hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not going to play it again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, lemme play the other side then.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Again, he prevents her from moving to the stereo and pulls her down onto the couch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now quit, Bobby. You said you're goin' a help me pick a song.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You said.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, lemme sing the one I picked an' see what you think... (she sings) "When there's a fire in your heart/Break the glass/Sound the alarm..."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He picks up one of the couch pillows and holds it over his ear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, you prick...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She pulls it from his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How 'bout if I just cut off your damn water?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm too moved by your gentility to speak.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She immediately softens and tries to become more "refined."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sugar, you know how I feel about you, don't you? I'm just tryin' to get you to take an interest in my kind a things, an' what I'm tryin' to do with myself... (bringing her face close to his) You know, there id'n anything in the world I wouldn't do for you, baby. I started livin' the day I found you, you know that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're playing the other side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very hurt, she sits up and looks away from him. He finishes the beer and holds the can out to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cerveza.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (grabbing it from him) Serveza yourself!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (she stands up) No, dammit, I would easy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And, as she turns and goes toward the kitchen:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you heal fast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Through the open door to the kitchen, Rayette can be seen opening the refrigerator. She takes out a can of beer and returns to Bobby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (over the above) You can play the piano, an' your whole damn family can play on some type a musical instrument. An' all I'm askin' is for you to listen to my singing for one single little second...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She hands him the can and sits back down on the couch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you think you would? No, you're too damn selfish...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He gestures at the name tag on her dress, and, as we'll find he often does, speaks in the Okie-Arky accent he's learned from working the rigs:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why'nt you take 'at sign off your tit, Ray, an' let's go on out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Out where?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She sits down and begins removing the tag.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know, I'll holler up Elton an' Stoney...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She thinks about it, then moves closer to him and begins unbuttoning his workshirt, as:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll go out with you, or I'll stay here, and do anything you'd like for me to do... if you'll just do one thing. If you'll tell me that you love me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can sing the song.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (annoyed) You know what, you are never satisfied.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right, hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The response makes her deeply insecure and she immediately lays her body against his...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, now, baby...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... and initiates another round of kissing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bobby lifts his ball from the return rack, moves to the lane and bowls a perfect strike. Making a self congratulatory gesture of triumph, he turns back to:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elton, seated at the scoring table. His wife, STONEY, is seated beside Rayette on the horseshoe banquette. As he addresses Rayette, we note that Elton's two front teeth are missing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Okie accent) Your ball, Ray.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reluctant) Is this suppose to be fun?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go on, get up there...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She rises and moves to the rack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... and stay relaxed this time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Picking up ball, she moves to the head of the lane and slings it down the alley, watching hopefully as...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... it rolls off to the right and takes only one pin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as she moves to her second ball.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now don't loft it, just release it like I told you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as she bowls the ball down the right-hand rut and comes back to the banquette, apologizing:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The ball's too heavy for me, honey...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks past her to Stoney, about to bowl her ball.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not the damn ball.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And as Stoney bowls a strike, Rayette hugs his arm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm tryin', baby, so don't start gettin' mad now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I'm not mad at you, hand. It'll be all right. Just spot and follow through...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And as Elton bowls a strike...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (mumbling) Shit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He gets up and passes Elton on his way to the rack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nice ball, El.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rayette, to Stoney as she watches Bobby prepare to bowl:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Id'n he somethin' to see?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And as he makes another strike and returns to the banquette, she gets up and throws her arms around him. He returns her embrace, smiling over her shoulder at:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two heavily made-up young women (TWINKY and BETTY) taking possession of the adjacent lane. (Note that Betty is of diminutive proportions, while Twinky is Amazonian.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is it my turn again?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right. Now show me a little somethin' this time, okay? Give me some form...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He remains standing, watching as she throws another gutter ball and then comes back toward him, alibi ing:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't help it, honey, the ball just keeps goin' cocky wobbly on me...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will you just do what the hell I tell you...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I did, didn' I, El?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got another ball comin'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She moves to the rack and, concentrating hard, advances down the lane and releases the ball. It rolls slowly down the center, hits at precisely the right spot and clears the pins.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Atta boy, Ray!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ecstatic, she comes back to the banquette, seating herself beside Bobby and trying to solicit a response from him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That was damn good, wad'n it? I finally did it...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, great. (begins removing his bowling shoes) Why don't you throw Z's for 19 frames, and then roll a strike on the last ball in the last frame of a losing game? Just wonderful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Turning to address the two young women over the back of the banquette.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wasn't it, ladies?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pointing at herself) Are you talking to us?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rayette pulls off her rental shoes and throws them to the floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm gonna go wait in the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He stretches his arms out on the back of the banquette as though he intends to reside there awhile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, why don't you do that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She grabs her sling-back and her purse and as she gets up:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait an I'll I go with you, honey...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As she picks up her belongings and follows Rayette:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (changing his shoes) We gotta get on home an' relieve the sitter. Why'nt you an' Ray come on over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. Go ahead. I'll settle up for the beers... (hands him the bowling shoes) An' walk Rayette over with you, will you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elton moves off and Bobby, now full of remorse, slumps into a depressed reverie. Beyond him, Betty and Twinky, can be seen, engaged in some discussion concerning him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A WAITRESS with a tray approaches and leans down to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I get you anything else?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. How much do I owe you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Five'll do it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He takes some loose bills from his pocket and lays them on her tray. She thanks him and moves off. As he reaches down and pulls on one of his boots, Twinky approaches behind him and leans down over the back of the banquette.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We been wantin' to ask you something. Are you the guy on YV?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Am I on TV?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pointing lo Betty) She says you're the one that sells all the cars on TV.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I don't claim to have sold 'em all. They still have some left, I believe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Betty appears on the other side of the banquette.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See, I told you it was him... (then to Bobby) Your name's Donnie something, right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I leave it to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My name is Shirley, but they call me Betty, and her name's Twinky.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking to Twinky) Twinky?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (explaining) Yeah, 'cause she's so "twinky"...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking from one to the other) Well, Betty and Twinky, it sure is nice talking to you girls. I just wish I had more time...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's a wig you wear, isn't it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (touching his hair) A wig?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I told her it was you, but that you're wearing a wig, 'cause on TV you're mostly bald in the front.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Twinky) Your little friend's real sharp there... (to Betty) Yeah, I don't like to wear the wig on TV, because with two and a half million people watching you, you've gotta be sincere. I just like to wear it when I'm out slippin' around bowling alleys an' things like that. I think it gives me a little more class, don't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, definitely...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking at his hairline) Yeah, but I can see a little bitty of the net up there, that's what give it away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's so weird to see you in person, but that's who she says you are.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to her) It is him, he said it's him. (to Bobby) Aren't you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, you could say it's me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Twinky reaches over to the scoring table, picking up a pencil and a score sheet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm gonna give you our number, Donnie, just in case... (as she writes) We're both professionals, if you didn't guess.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, you seem very professional...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (handing the score sheet to him) I always tell everyone the same thing. I got rolled and beat up real bad recently, and since then it's two for one, an' I work strictly in tandem with Betty...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He glances at the dwarfish Betty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I can see how she'd come in handy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rayette sits sulking in Bobby's car. He comes up to the passenger window and leans down to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on. We're goin' over to Elton's.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You just going to sit there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. Hope no one hits on you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hope they do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He casually slaps the outside of the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See you later, then...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He walks off through the lot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: staring out through the windshield.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as he stops and comes back to the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No one would want to hit on you, you look too pathetic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No response.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, DiPesto. We can still have a good time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're the pathetic one, not me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going on over there...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not some piece a crap.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know you're not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You treat me like I was.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (close to tears) You go slippin' around in front a my face, an' in front a Elton an' Stoney. What do you imagine they think a someone you treat that way...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, hand...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He opens the door and gets inside, putting his arm around her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elton and Stoney know how I feel about you. An' they're just goin' to think I'm not too nice a guy, which I'm not, an' that you're a hell of a person puttin' up with me, that's all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're goin' a find me dead one time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sssh, come on now... (he kisses her) Be a good girl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you really want a get up an' leave me, you can read about it in the newsprint.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not going to get up an' leave you. (kisses her again, then:) Now let's go over to El's an' have a good time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you love me, Bobby?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hesitates briefly, then:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well now, what do you think?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Though hardly an undying declaration, it's close enough to fill her with forgiveness. Reaching over, she pulls him into her arms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: KALEIDOSCOPIC SERIES OF SCENES, showing Elton and Bobby WORKING THE RIG as part of a four-man team. The DRILLER stands back, giving them directives, while the prestigious DERRICKMAN, the "star" of the team, lounges around in the b.g. Though he has been working the fields for some months, it is apparent that Bobby is still somewhat of a novice in the operations of the rig.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FADE OVER ABOVE ACTIONS, to:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An impromptu card game, taking place on a lunch break.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (IMPROVISED) Bobby, in a buoyant mood, lays down a winning poker hand and rakes in a pile of bills and change lying on the table. The participants include Elton and THREE OTHER TOOLPUSHERS. In the b.g., as the game continues, other "HANDS" can be seen changing clothes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bobby sits morosely on the couch beside Twinky. One of his arms is around her, the other holds a can of beer. Both he and Twinky are looking at...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Elton, who rides Betty on his leg as both sing "Ride a Cockhorse To Banbury Cross." She begins to laugh with the hysterical abandon of a child, and Elton, nearly beside himself, looks over to Bobby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God, id'n she the cutest damn thing in your life!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (ELTON SINGING A RANK DOGHOUSE SONG OVER:)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Having been up all night, drinking, they move unsteadily toward a derrick and are intercepted by the driller as they climb the stairs to the rig floor. He informs them they are unfit to work and "impolitely" eighty-sixes them for the day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (ELTON SINGING OVER:)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bobby's car slows as it moves into a freeway jam.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He gestures out at the traffic as Elton, strumming a ukelele, concludes his song.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can you believe this shit?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He takes a drink from a half pint of bard liquor, then angrily hits at the steering wheel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goddamned freeway... Jesus Christ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A few cars ahead, a truck can be seen carrying several furniture pieces protected by padded covers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Give 'em the horn, Bob.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look at these assholes! What the hell are they doing?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The assholes are going nowhere and other cars close up behind and to both sides of Bobby's car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He suddenly throws the car into "park"...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't take this shit anymore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... opens the door and gets out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: moving down the freeway, away from his car. Behind, Elton can be seen sliding over into the driver's seat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as Bobby steps up onto the fender of a car, looking for the cause of the jam.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, get off my car!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where the hell's he goin'?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bobby cuts in front of another car and climbs up into the rear of the truck. Moving to the front of it, he looks out over the cab.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: POV of the glut of cars in all four lanes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Bob! Come on! Quit foolin' around!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On his way out of the truck, Bobby pauses to look beneath one of the padded protectors, then pulls it off to reveal an upright piano. He leans down to the keyboard and plays a few notes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elton, amused.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shit, what's he doin'?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bobby has pulled the bench out from beneath the piano and, sitting himself, begins to play a Chopin prelude.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elton can be seen applauding him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: playing as the traffic begins to move and the truck with it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Again, Elton leans out the window, yelling at him:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You better get your butt off there, Bob! Come on, now!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The right-turn indicator is flashing and the truck begins to work its way across the lanes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: of Bobby playing, as the truck heads for an off ramp.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: honking the horn and flailing his arm out the window as he tries to cross lanes. The traffic closes on his right, preventing him from following.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: hemmed into the left-hand lanes, and the truck, with Bobby still playing, pulling away on the off ramp.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (CHOPIN PRELUDE OVER:)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The truck slows and comes to a stop at a signal. Bobby jumps out and moves to the sidewalk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FOLLOWING with him as he wanders, boozed and aimless, along the dispirited cheap streets of the city.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rayette clears some plates from an empty table and, crossing the diner, sees...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Bobby entering. As he takes a seat at the counter, she goes about her tasks, ignoring him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He watches her as she moves to the only other customer and totals his bill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another waitress appears with a coffee Silex. She gestures it at Bobby and he nods. As she pours him a cup, Rayette moves to the register, deposits some bills, then turns and exits to the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bobby leans against a pickup adjacent to Rayette's car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She comes out of the rear door of the diner, hesitates as she sees him, then moves past him to her car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was with Elton last night, Ray.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maintaining her attitude of suffered injustice, she reaches to the car door and opens it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's the truth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He reaches behind her and pushes the door shut. Then gently taking hold of her arm, he turns her toward him, bringing his face close to hers...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rayette...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... and as she turns away, be begins to kiss her neck. She lowers her gaze to the ground, quietly uttering:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You son of a bitch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bobby, Elton and Stoney are seated on the couch, all looking toward the TV, playing an old black-and white. Rayette is seated on an adjacent chair, holding an infant in her lap, cooing and fawning over it throughout the following.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I swore to God I'd never hire on to this type a work again. Christ, I don't know how the hell I let you talk me into it...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rayette reaches over to Bobby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Give me a swig, hon'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hands her his beer and as she takes a sip and hands it back:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You didn' know I was a derrickman once, did you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bobby shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Down in the southern fields, an' man, did I hate it. An' Stoney's brother was a well-puller, wad'n he, honey? The one with three fingers?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (her eyes on the TV) My brother Cruser, yeah...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I once hung suspendered 90 feet up on a tour, like a damn circus artist...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Honey, took at this little bugger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Near broke my damn neck...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Id'n he the cutest little guy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very cute... Put it down, an' let's go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elton turns to him with a gap-toothed smile:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, you oughta get you one them things, Bob.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as he stands up...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (standing up) Yeah... (stretching his arms) An' I oughta live in a trailer park with my front teeth poked out...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: seated on the rig floor opposite Bobby, who eats a sandwich, as:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, what if she was, Bob? I can't see nothin' so bad in it...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bobby scowls hostilely at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What if I was to let you in on the little fact that she is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks away from Elton, not wanting to hear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right. She told me. An' she's all tore up about it, which I hate a see.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as he continues:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hell, id'n it just somethin' to face up to? I'll tell you, somewhere along the line, you even get to likin' the whole idea...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I recall when Stoney first give me the news, I could a shit...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bobby throws his sandwich onto the rig floor near Elton's leg. He looks down at a spatter of mayonnaise on his pants.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, id'n that nice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (attacking the messenger) It's ridiculous! I'm sitting here, listening to some asshole cracker compare his life to mine!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He spills out the remainder of coffee from his cup and screws it onto the top of a thermos.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just keep telling me about the good life, Elton, if you want a see me puke my lunch!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elton reaches down and wipes the mayonnaise off his pant leg.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you're sayin' you're somethin' better'n what I am, that's one thing. But I can't say much a someone who'd run off an' leave a woman in a situation like this an' feel easy about it. An' that's all I gotta say.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hope that's all you gotta say, El, 'cause I'm about as tired of your mouth as I am workin' this stinkin' hole!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He grabs his jacket and his lunch bucket, jumps down off the rig and begins walking toward his car parked by the Field Office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the b.g., Elton gets up and hurls his hard hat toward Bobby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shit ass!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he approaches his car, he looks toward the  Field Office, where...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... The driller is leaning down to a car with TWO MEN in it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: calling over to him:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Longcipher! I'm quitting!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The driller gestures a direction to the driver of the car, and as it pulls off, he moves toward the office:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Longcipher! I'm talking to you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The driller opens the office door and looks back to Bobby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you hear me?! I said I'm quitting!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't give a shit what you do. You ben more trouble than you're worth, an' I'm damn glad to be rid of both a you assholes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He goes into the office and closes the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: throwing his jacket and his lunch bucket into his car. As he starts to get in, his attention is drawn back to the rig.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The car that held the two men is parked next to it, and both men are on the rig platform moving toward Elton. He backs away from them, breaks toward the rig tour and starts to climb it. One of the men catches hold of his leg and yanks him back. Elton pulls loose from him, jumps to the ground and begins running with both men in pursuit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey! What's goin' on?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He starts sprinting back to the rig.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The first man has a hold on Elton and is struggling to subdue him. He is joined by the second man, and as they force his arms behind his back and cuff his wrists...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Bobby MOVES INTO FRAME, grabbing onto the first man and wrestling him away from Elton.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't do that, Bob!! It's the Law!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bobby hurls the man onto the ground and turns around to go after the second man, struggling with Elton.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's the Law, Bob, don't mix in!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The second man pushes Elton aside and as Bobby throws a punch at him...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look out behind!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... the other grabs him from behind, holding him, while the second man jams a fist into his stomach and, as he doubles over, follows with a violent chop to the back of his neck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bobby slumps to the ground, and as the first man puts a knee into his back and prepares to handcuff him:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, don't do that. Don't you think you could just leave him...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The second man takes hold of Elton and starts to move him off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure as hell he wouldn' a done that if he'd known who you was... Would you, Bob?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bobby, dazed, raises his head from the dirt, looking toward Elton.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Christ Almighty, what's happening here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, let him go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he starts pushing a resistant Elton toward the car, Bobby sits up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell me what in the hell's going on, Elton!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got accused a robbin' a fillin'station down in the Indian Nation, didn' I tell you...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got wild an' jumped my bail...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Move it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He takes him roughly by the arm and moves off with the first man following.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (over his shoulder, to Bobby) An' here they come runnin' after me a year later... Ain't that somethin'?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: looking toward:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The two men forcing Elton into the rear seat of the car, as he calls back to Bobby:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell Stoney for me, will you?! Tell her to come get me...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They close the door on him and get into the car. As it drives off...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bobby sits watching until it disappears from sight, then he sits back against a pump casing and drops his head onto his chest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She opens her mouth and rends the air with a keening wail. Her face beads with moisture and journeys through expressions indistinguishable from grief and anguish. Presently, an ecstatic and very professional screech issues from her, after which she reaches up and pulls Bobby down onto her, breathing into his ear...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Donnie, oh Donnie...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (BACH PARTITA FAINTLY UNDER:)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bobby, dressed in a suit and tie, moves through a network of hallways, checking the door numbers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He arrives at a door designated as Studio A, and, after hesitating for a moment, opens it and steps inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (BACH PARTITA UNDER:)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TWO RECORDING ENGINEERS glance at him without interest and return to their dials and needles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bobby looks from them through the glass partition to the recording studio in view beyond.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELIZABETH "TITA" DUPEA is at the piano, intensely into the Bach. She wears a monastic-looking dress, her unruly hair is pinned back from her face, and her glasses lie on the bench beside her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: watching her with both affection and appreciation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She is "sounding" as she plays, in tones out-of-key and discordant with the Bach.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There she goes again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bobby glances over at him, then looks back to Tita.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She hunches over the keyboard and plays an arpeggio, humming a long monochromatic note.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My 1-year-old can carry a tune better than that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bobby is about to defend her, when the engineer flips a toggle switch and addresses the mike feeding into the studio:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss Dupea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is no response and she continues playing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (more emphatic) Miss Dupea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (annoyed) Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bobby can be seen in the b.g., having difficulty restraining his irritation under the following:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd like to remind you again, this isn't an opera or a musical comedy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh... I'm sorry. Was I singing again?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you want to call it that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, you have to simply tell me, that's all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's exactly what I am doing, again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you have to let me get halfway through the movement first? This is tiring me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have a suggestion. Why don't we take a break.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, for pity's sake...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She puts her elbows on top of the piano and drops her head into her bands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is she going to cry again?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want to take a break.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What would you like in your coffee?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She makes a mumbled response, her head still in her bands:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you tell her Bobby's here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to the mike) Miss Dupea, Bobby's here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She raises her head, squints toward the booth, then grabs her glasses from the bench and puts them on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bobby enters the studio and comes toward her, opening his arms. She rushes into his embrace, burying her face in his shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (very emotional) Oh my goodness... Bobby...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi, Tita.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She raises her head to look at him, and verging on tears:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Robert Eroica...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now don't...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I'm not... (taking a deep breath, then:) I'm not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tita sits on the piano bench, crying and searching through her purse for a tissue. Bobby hovers behind her, gently patting her on the back and glancing with some embarrassment toward the recording booth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just can't look at you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't, then.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As she blows her nose into the tissue, a young man comes into view, hands Bobby a paper cup and leaves. Tita takes another tissue from her purse and dabs at her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You always do this to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I don't mean to. (setting the cup down on the piano) Here's your tea, Tita.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you... (then:) Oh no, don't put it on there...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She quickly picks up the cup and places it on the floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (caressing the piano) This is a very special, very old CB 275...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know who it once belonged to?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Waldnit von Schnechter. Prewar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (politely) No kidding.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He sits down on the bench beside her...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It has absolutely no objectionable idiosyncrasies...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... and tests it out with a brief flourish on the keys. She watches him, then:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Robert...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (stops playing) Very nice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have to talk seriously with you...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everybody still up on the Island?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, Herbert's mostly on the mainland because of the orchestra, so at the moment, there's just Daddy, Carl and myself... and Van Oost.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's Van Oost?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (not fond of the subject) Catherine -- she's a pianist. She's working with Carl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carl's a fiddler. What's he doing coaching piano?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, 11 months ago he was on his bicycle, on his way to the post office in La Roche... and he ran into a Jeep and sprained his neck...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bobby laughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sprained his neck?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tita laughs, then:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not funny. He permanently sprained his neck, and since then it's been extremely difficult for him to tuck the violin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crashes into a Jeep and totals his neck. (shaking his head) That's Carl...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Robert, I have to tell you something...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Daddy's very ill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, well, what, what's he...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's had two strokes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks away from her, not wanting to hear any more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's not... They feel he... maybe he might not recover, and that he'll either...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (standing up) Don't tell me about this...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He moves away from the piano and Tita turns to look at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But don't you think it's right, though, that you should see him, at least once...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (miked) We're ready Miss Dupea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to the booth) Just a minute, please! (to Bobby) Robert, don't you think it's right that you should see him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He moves aimlessly about trying to subdue his anguish.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah... I guess so...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going back up tonight. Will you go with me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He glances at her, catching her profound disappointment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd rather drive up myself and... maybe go into Canada after... And I can't stay long, Tita, probably a week, at the most.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks toward the booth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well... (then, to Tita) I better let you...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She gets up from the bench and goes to him, taking hold of his arm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll walk out with you...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As they move to the hall door, she addresses the booth:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll be back in two minutes!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cut that in half, will you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She smiles at Bobby as they go out into hall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They hate me, I feel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: down the hallway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe you better stay, then.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I need to talk to you, about so many things...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I'll be seeing you in a couple of days, won't I?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They stop at the stairway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh God, I'm so glad, Robert, that you're coming...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, me, too...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It'll be so good for you, and for Daddy, because you know, you've never really...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (cutting her off) Tita, I've got to go...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He kisses her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Feeling herself about to break down again, she attempts a valiant smile and stands watching as...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Bobby turns and goes down the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (TAMMY WYNETTE'S "D-I-V-O-R-C-E" OVER:)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: moving from his car, up the walkway and entering Rayette's house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: playing the above song.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: looking from...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... a rumpled blanket on the couch, to...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... a can of beer and a lighted cigarette burning in an ashtray on the coffee table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calling out) Hello?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He crosses to a hall and moves down toward the bedroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have the day off?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He steps into the doorway, to see:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rayette, lying in bed, her back against the pillows, staring at the wall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you sick?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No response.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You heard about Elton, I guess.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She turns her gaze to the window. He looks at her briefly, then:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, I get your point.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he moves to the closet:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hope you didn't strain yourself, getting in here and into your pose before I hit the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He picks up a suitcase from the closet floor, grabs some of his clothes from the rack, and, moving to a chair, sets the suitcase on it and begins packing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have to go home. My father's sick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rayette turns on her side, making a snorting sound of disbelief.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, it's very funny.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He moves to a dresser, extracts his underwear and returns to the suitcase.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll be gone two or three weeks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (not looking at him) You'll be gone, period.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He closes the suitecase, secures it...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll try and call you from up there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... and picking it up, moves around the bed toward the door. He stops, setting the suitcase on the bed and looking down at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She is still faced away from him, her shoulders trembling as she weeps soundlessly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (very emotional) Come on, DiPesto. I never told you it would work out to anything. Did I?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks away from her, to the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll send you some money, that's all I can do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Returning his gaze to her:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And... I'll call you, like I said... (he pauses, then) Bye, Ray.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An audible sob finally comes from her. Bobby quickly picks up the suitcase and moves out of the bedroom and down the hall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as he moves into view. He throws the suitcase in through the rear window, moves around to the driver's side and gets in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He starts the motor, angrily throws it into gear and places his hands on the wheel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BOBBY'S HAND slashes at the arm of the record player, pulling it across the grooves and stifling Tammy Wynette.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you want to go with me, Ray?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His car moves north along the Pacific Coast Highway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (WYNETTE OVER:)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: looking over at Rayette and smiling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She returns his look with absolute devotion, then reaches over and caresses the back of his neck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (WYNETTE OVER:)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OUT PAST Bobby's profile, to a Southern California pastoral landscape passing by.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: singing the above song.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "There's been hot spells/An' cold spells ever since we met/I've seen your small fires/Your big fires/But I won't give up yet/Oh someday you'll yearn/'Cause your heart's gonna burn/For that old familiar glow/You'll be burned..."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bobby laughs and she looks over at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You like it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I love it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (resumes singing) "You'll be burned out/Or smoked out/An' come back to me, I know..."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bobby's attention is taken by something on the road ahead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Every trail that you blaze/Makes me..."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the hell is that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: of a car lying upside down on the left side of the highway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TWO FIGURES are standing beside it, engaged in a heated argument.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is it an accident?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bobby pulls off onto the right-hand shoulder, stops the car and gets out. He moves out to the center line, looking across the road, to:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A long-haired young woman (PALM) in Levi's and parka, presently pushing her close-cropped, boyish looking friend (TERRY) against the side of the car and making some indecipherable accusation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey! What's going on, what's the trouble?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The young woman turns and gives him the finger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rotate, mack!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: sticking her head out the driver's window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What'd she say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: gesturing angrily back at the wreck as she crosses toward Bobby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look at my car! Piece of shit! I just bought it brand new from a used-car lot, and the steering goes to the pot on me!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're lucky no one was hurt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seven hundred dollars, down the toilet! I'd like to go back and punch the son of a bitch out! Can you give us a lift?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Without waiting for a response, she moves back to Terry, who is retrieving some of their belongings from the highway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, Terry, we got a ride!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus, what a rude person...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Palm and Terry, still under the spell of their roadside tiff, sit in sulky silence in the back seat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bobby glances at Palm in the rear view.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's your name?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Palm Apodaca.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rayette turns around and, thinking Terry is a boy, asks rather flirtatiously:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An' what's your name?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Terry Grouse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shocked at the female voice coming from "him," she turns back around and pokes Bobby on the leg.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (loudly) What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (low tones) I'll tell you... (spelling out) ... l-a-t-e-r.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How far are you going to?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Washington.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll get off in Washington and hook another ride.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where are you going?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alaska.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alaska? Are you on vacation?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sullenly) She wants to live there, because she thinks it's cleaner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cleaner than what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Terry) You don't have to tell everybody about it. Pretty soon they'll all go there and it won't be so clean.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you know it's clean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I saw a picture of it. Alaska is very clean. It appeared to look very white to me... Don't you think?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. That's before the big thaw.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She leans forward, looking annoyed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Before the what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (COUNTRY & WESTERN INSTRUMENTAL OVER:)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: moving through the Redwood country above San Francisco.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: bored, as he drives. Beside him, Rayette primps in the sunvisor mirror.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Terry lights a cigarette while Palm, staring morosely out the window, goes into a soliloquy:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I had to leave this place. I got depressed, seeing all the crap. And the thing is, they're making more crap, you know? They've got so many stores and stuff and junk full of crap, I can't believe it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who? People, that's who! Pretty soon there won't be room for anyone. They're selling more crap that people go and buy than you can imagine. Oofh! Crap! I believe everybody should have a big hole where they throw in all this stuff and burn it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rayette leans around to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There'd never be a hole big enough. Now took at me, for instance, when I was just one person, before Bobby, I had so much garbage collectin' onto me every day, I was thinkin' about gettin a dispose all...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A dispose-all, what's that but more crap? I've never seen such crap. Oofh, I don't know how people get up in the morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mass production is what does it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean "mass"... I have to come out and tell you, you're not that clean, either.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait a minute. I'm not that neat, maybe, but I am clean.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, you're not that bad, but some people... I mean, people's homes, just filth. I've been in people's homes...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In my personal observation, I think that more people are neat than are clean...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In my personal thing, I don't see that. I'm seeing more filth. A lot of filth. What they need to do every day, no, once in a while, is a cockroach thing, where they spray the homes. And uh... can you imagine, if their doors were painted a pretty color, and they had a pot outside, with...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, it could be adorable...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And they picked up! I mean, it wouldn't be filthy, with Coke bottles and whiskey, and those signs everywhere...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She gestures angrily out the window at the roadside billboards.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... they oughta be erased! All those signs, selling crap, and more crap, and, I don't know, it's disgusting, I don't even want to talk about it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bobby starts to say something:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's just filthy. People are dirty. I think that's the biggest thing that's wrong with people. I think they wouldn't be as violent if they were clean, because then they wouldn't have anybody to pick on... Oofh... Dirt...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not dirt. See, dirt isn't bad. It's filth. Filth is bad. That's what starts maggots and riots...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She suddenly leans over to the front seat, pointing to a semi ahead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, follow that truck. They know the best places to stop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's an old maid's tale.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bullshit! Truck drivers know the best eating places on the road.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rayette turns around, asserting:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Salesmen and cops are the ones. If you'd ever waitressed, honey, you'd know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't call me "honey," mack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't call me "mack," honey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wouldn't be a waitress. They're nasty and full of crap.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You better hold onto your tongue!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (giving her the finger) Hold onto this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Terry laughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just one minute, you! Don't you ever talk to me like that!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shut up! All of you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All four are seated at a booth. The women have given their orders and a WAITRESS stands above Bobby, waiting for his:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking at his menu) I'll have an omelette, no potatoes. Give me tomatoes instead, and wheat toast instead of rolls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The waitress indicates something on the menu with the butt of her pencil.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No substitutions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What does that mean? You don't have any tomatoes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (annoyed) No. We have tomatoes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I can't have any. Is that what you mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Only what's on the menu... (again, indicating  with her pencil) A Number Two: Plain omelette. It comes with cottage fries and rolls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know what it comes with, but that's not what I want.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll come back when you've made up your mind...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She starts to move away and Bobby detains her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait, I've made up my mind. I want a plain omelette, forget the tomatoes, don't put potatoes on the plate, and give me a side of wheat toast and a cup of coffee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, we don't have side orders of toast. I can give you an English muffin or a coffee roll.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean, you don't have side orders of toast? You make sandwiches, don't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you like to talk to the manager?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, mack!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Palm) Shut up. (to the waitress) You have bread, don't you, and a toaster of some kind?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't make the rules.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, I'll make it as easy for you as I can. Give me an omelette, plain, and a chicken salad sandwich on wheat toast -- no butter, no mayonnaise, no lettuce -- and a cup of coffee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She begins writing down his order, repeating it sarcastically:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One Number Two, and a chicken sal san -- hold the butter, the mayo, the lettuce -- and a cup of coffee... Anything else?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now all you have to do is hold the chicken, bring me the toast, charge me for the sandwich, and you haven't broken any rules.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (challenging him) You want me to hold the chicken.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. I want you to hold it between your knees.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The other three laugh, and the waitress points to a "Right to Refuse" sign above the counter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You see that sign, sir?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bobby glances over at it, then back to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll all have to leave, I'm not taking any more of your smartness and your sarcasm!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He smiles politely at her, then:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You see this sign?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He reaches his arm out and "clears" the table for her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: in the back seat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fantastic! That you could figure all that out, and lay that down on her, to come up with a way you could get your toast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't get it, did I?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, but it was very clever... I would of just punched her out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (COUNTRY & WESTERN OVER:)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: moving through the Northwest coastal region.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Palm resumes her monologue:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: People... Oofh... (shaking her head in utter disgust) Animals are not like that... They're always cleaning themselves. Did you ever see... What are they called? Pigeons!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks over at Terry, slumped in her seat, asleep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's always picking on himself and his friends. They're always picking bugs out of their hair...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: asleep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Monkeys, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Except monkeys do things out in the open that I don't go for.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: benumbed, his eyes glazed over as he stares out through the windshield.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was in this place once, this store, with snakes, monkeys, everything you could imagine. I walked in, I had to run out. It stunk! They didn't even have an incense going...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Though no one listens, she goes on, working herself up:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you know, I read where they invented this car that runs on... that runs on... when you boil water...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (half-dead) Steam.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right, steam. A car you could ride around in and not cause a stink. But do you know, they will not even let us have it. Can you believe it? Why?! Man! He likes to create a stink. I wrote them a note once, and told them to clean it... I mean, don't you see that? It's just filthy! I mean, I've seen filth you wouldn't believe! Oofh, what a stink! I don't even want to talk about it...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (WYNETTE'S "WHEN THERE'S A FIRE" OVER:)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: deposited at the side of the highway, with their luggage, duffle bags and television set lying on the road edge. Terry lifts a bored hand to wave at...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Bobby, behind the wheel. He waves back, pulls out onto the highway and drives off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (MUSIC FADES, AS:)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The car pulls into a motel parking slot and stops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bobby and Rayette in bed. She lies on her side, watching him watch TV. After a moment:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you depressed about your daddy, honey?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I 'magine it's me then, id'n it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is what you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're depressed that I come along.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who said I was depressed?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, is that a happy face I see?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No response.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Cause if it was me, I could just catch a Greyhound back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, you're not going to kill yourself this time. I wish I'd known...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns off the light on the night stand and rolls onto his side, faced away from her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They lie silently in the dark for a moment. Then:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know if I'm gonna be able to sleep or not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No response.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking over at him) Hint, hint.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No response.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sighing; then:) I guess I'll just have to count the sheep. (closing her eyes) One-two-three-four...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She opens her eyes and looks over at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seven... eight... (caressing his shoulder) Look at this old cold shoulder, what am I gonna do with it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks around at her and with gentle good humor:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you just wouldn't open your mouth, everything would be fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She turns an imaginary key at her lips.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tick a lock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He rolls over to face her and, yielding to her request, begins to make love to ber.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rayette following after Bobby. As he moves to his car, he removes some cash from his wallet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why can't I go out to your folks' house? Give me one good reason.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have to see how things are first. My father's sick, you understand? They wouldn't be prepared for me bringing anyone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He holds out a roll of bills and as she takes them:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So how long am I supposed to sit an' twiddle my thumbs in this place?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you can't do what I ask, Ray, use that money to go back home, then.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bobby, don't talk like that...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She moves over to him and gives him a quick kiss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It'll be all right, I'll get a hold a some magazines an' things like that. An' maybe find a beauty salon an' get my hair fixed, okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: getting into the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, Ray...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Or maybe sit out by the pool an' get myself nice an' tan for you. Would you like that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (starting the engine) Sure...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It brings out my eyes...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bye, honey, I'll call you in a couple of days.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She watches unhappily as he backs out of the slot and the car pulls away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bye, baby...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bobby gets out of his car and wanders the deck of the ferry. He stops to look out over the Sound to one of the islands off the Washington coast, then glances back to the mainland, receding in the distance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bobby drives off the ferry onto the island.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The car moves over a tree-lined country lane and presently turns off onto a private road, leading to a large Victorian-style house. It pulls to a stop behind two other cars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bobby gets out of the car and moves up the porch steps to the front door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSER ON him as he hesitates, listening briefly to the FAINT SOUND of two pianos coming from within.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then he opens the door and goes inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (TWO PIANOS OVER:)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bobby tentatively wanders the first floor of the house, taking in the ghosts of the past.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the living room, he pauses at a table to look at several framed photographs. He picks up one of his mother and father, looks closely at it, then gently returns it to its place and resumes wandering.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He stops at the music room and looks in through the half-opened door:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the far side of the room, near windows which give view to a verdant exterior, are two concert grands. His brother CARL is seated at one of the pianos, and a young woman (CATHERINE VAN OOST) is seated at the other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: looking from Carl, to Catherine. He watches her briefly, then steps out of the doorway...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... and moves down a hallway to a closed door. He reaches down and opens it, looking inside to:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: grooming the hair of an elderly man (NICHOLAS DUPEA) seated in a wheelchair with his back to Bobby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks up and, seeing Bobby, smiles happily, then reaches down and turns the wheelchair around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His eyes are half-closed and are cast down to the floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bobby moves over to him, bending down and looking into his face. Nicholas opens his eyes slightly and gazes through Bobby into an absolute elsewhere.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bobby raises his eyes to Tita.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He doesn't even know who the hell I am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nicholas Dupea sits at the head of the table, being fed his dinner by a male nurse (SPICER).

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bobby, at the opposite end of the table, is seated next to Tita. Unable to bear looking at his father, he glances over at Catherine, seated next to Carl on his right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She raises her eyes from her plate to ask him something, just as Tita is moved to reminisce:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Remember, Bobby, what mother used to say when...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Bobby) How long have you been... (To Tita) Oh, excuse me...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, it's all right, you go ahead...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was just going to ask Robert how long he's been away from here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Four or five years.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, the last time was three years ago.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh no, it's been much more than that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Away from the piano, Tita, you have no sense of time at all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think that's true.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is true.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Besides being very rude.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What have you been doing since then?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What have I been doing? Different things, different jobs, here and there. Nothing that interesting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you no longer play at all?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bobby starts to reply and is interrupted by:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, just after I came back off tour with the Betenthaller Quartet, Dad, myself and Herbert had a summit conference about you...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, my, "a summit conference." I wonder where I was, polishing silver behind the coal bin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know where you were, penis envy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
